item.title: Mark Carney Heads to Beijing to Discuss Canada-China Relations as U.S. Outlook Darkens
item.description: The prime minister is seeking new markets for Canadian goods and to mend relations with China after years of deep acrimony between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Yoan Valat
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada and his advisers have said that he is seeking a pragmatic thawing of Canada’s relationship with China.

item.title: Venezuela Frees Several Americans From Prison, U.S. Says
item.description: They were the first U.S. citizens released after the U.S. military captured Nicolás Maduro and flew him to the United States to stand trial on drug and other charges.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: El Helicoide prison in Caracas, Venezuela, is one of the main prisons in the country holding political prisoners.

item.title: Justice Dept. Memo Said Trump Could Send Troops Into Venezuela Unilaterally
item.description: The memo offers a detailed look into the administration’s legal justification for the military incursion into Venezuelan territory in early January.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration has started showing a Justice Department memo to members of Congress that broadly covers whether President Trump needed congressional authorization to direct the recent military operation in Venezuela.

item.title: Arrest Made in Toronto Airport Gold Heist as Police Seek 2 Others
item.description: The Canadian authorities have identified 10 people in connection with the theft of about $14.4 million in gold bars from Toronto Pearson International Airport in 2023.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Carlos Osorio/Reuters
item.media:description: A shipment of gold and money from Switzerland went missing in April 2023 after it was placed in an airport warehouse in Toronto.

item.title: Greenland Would Be the Largest U.S. Land Acquisition, if Trump Got His Way
item.description: Denmark does not want to sell its territory. But for a real estate mogul turned president, the world’s largest island may be irresistible.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue commemorating Hans Egede, the Danish missionary who founded Nuuk, the capital of Greenland.

item.title: The Sea Lions of the Galápagos Are Not Ready to Give Up Mother’s Milk
item.description: Animals that researchers call “supersucklers” come back to nurse even after they can hunt, mate and fend for themselves.
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: Venezuela’s Oil Riches Are Years Off, but Winners and Losers Will Emerge
item.description: Companies that already have operations in the country stand to benefit, but those that have profited from a standoff between Caracas and Washington could lose out.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Venezuela in 2020. Despite its massive oil reserves, Venezuela produces about 1 percent of the world’s oil.

item.title: Trump’s Plans for Venezuelan Oil Run Headlong Into Reality
item.description: President Trump’s fixation on Venezuela’s oil raises the question of how much “energy dominance” is really worth nowadays.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s attack on Venezuela has emerged as a unique opportunity to put into action what he has long called for: taking another country’s oil.

item.title: U.S. Attacked Boat With Aircraft That Looked Like a Civilian Plane
item.description: Even accepting the Trump administration’s claim that there is an armed conflict with suspected drug runners, the laws of war bar “perfidy.”
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Eric Schmitt, John Ismay, Julian E. Barnes, Riley Mellen and Christiaan Triebert
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth in the Capitol last week.

item.title: In Venezuela, Amnesty for Political Prisoners Stokes Hope and Frustration
item.description: Venezuela’s new leaders and President Trump have alluded to a major release of political prisoners, but the liberations have been slow to come.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Miguel Gutierrez/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The opposition politician Juan Pablo Guanipa, in Caracas in 2020.

item.title: Venezuela Frees 24 More Political Prisoners, Rights Group Says
item.description: Since an interim government began the releases last week, at least 41 people have been let go, according to Foro Penal.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members of political prisoners waiting for releases outside the Rodeo I prison on Friday.

item.title: Russian Missiles Failed in Venezuela During U.S. Attack
item.description: The Venezuelan regime had high-powered air defense systems from its allies in the Kremlin, but failed to set much of it up.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib, Eric Schmitt, Christiaan Triebert and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed Buk launcher at La Carlota air base in Caracas after the U.S. strikes.

item.title: Guantánamo Prison Enters 25th Year
item.description: The prison has outlasted the war in Afghanistan, has employed tens of thousands of temporary troops and holds six men charged but not yet tried in death penalty cases.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Trump Shakes up Latin American Politics
item.description: The U.S. capture of Nicolás Maduro has divided the region. But every nation wants to avoid being next.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Government supporters calling for the release of Nicolás Maduro in Caracas, Venezuela, last week.

item.title: Trump Threats and Venezuela Strike Leave Mexico Agonizing Over How to Respond
item.description: President Claudia Sheinbaum and her inner circle have been grappling with the right tone to strike in the country’s response to the Venezuela strike for fear of antagonizing the White House.
item.dc:creator: Paulina Villegas and James Wagner
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico has tried to thread a narrow diplomatic needle in the aftermath of the U.S. strike in Venezuela.

item.title: Venezuela’s New Leader Enlists U.S. Troops to Bring a Rogue Ship Back
item.description: Delcy Rodríguez got American help with the return of an oil tanker linked to one of her political rivals that had left the country without authorization.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Christiaan Triebert
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, the interim leader of Venezuela, in the country’s capital, Caracas, on Monday.

item.title: Machado Offered Trump Her Nobel, but Prize Institute Says It’s Not Allowed
item.description: After María Corina Machado, Venezuela’s opposition leader, offered her Nobel Peace Prize to President Trump, the Norwegian Nobel Institute said it cannot be “transferred to others.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado, Venezuela’s opposition leader, offered to give her Nobel Peace Prize to President Trump, who has long coveted the award.

item.title: Chrystia Freeland Resigns as a Member of Canada’s Parliament
item.description: Once a powerful force under Justin Trudeau, Chrystia Freeland ended her time in politics on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chrystia Freeland, who resigned from Parliament on Friday, at her home in Toronto.

item.title: How Delcy Rodríguez, Venezuela’s Leader, Became Vital to Trump’s Plans for the Country
item.description: Delcy Rodríguez, a guerrilla’s daughter, started out as a provocateur. She pivoted to revive a ravaged economy, making her vital to U.S. plans to run Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, then Venezuela’s vice president, during an interview last year.

item.title: How Wagner Moura Stayed True to Himself and Earned a Golden Globe Nomination
item.description: The Brazilian star of “The Secret Agent” is a major Oscar contender, though some at home turned against him for criticizing the right-wing government.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan and Sela Shiloni

item.title: After President’s Capture, U.S. and Venezuela Explore Restoring Diplomatic Ties
item.description: The move embodied the contradictions and fast-changing nature of the two countries’ relationship.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States Embassy in Caracas, Venezuela, in 2019.

item.title: Minnesota Woman Dies After Shark Bite in U.S. Virgin Islands, Authorities Say
item.description: People at the beach went to the woman’s rescue and helped her ashore, the authorities said, but she died at a hospital.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodríguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The woman was at a beach on the island of St. Croix when a shark bit her, the authorities said.

item.title: Trump Urges Oil Companies to Speed Work in Venezuela
item.description: The president met with executives on a day when the U.S. seized another tanker carrying Venezuelan oil.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, Eric Schmitt and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and members of his cabinet at a meeting with oil executives at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Outside Prisons in Caracas, Venezuelans Anxiously Await Release of More Political Detainees
item.description: Venezuela’s interim government said it would release an “important number” of imprisoned people, but only nine have been confirmed freed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members awaiting the release of prisoners outside El Helicoide, a notorious prison in the center of Caracas, the Venezuelan capital, on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Threatens to Take Greenland ‘the Hard Way’
item.description: The president continued to advance an imperialist vision of American foreign policy, where the U.S. can dominate neighboring countries “whether they like it or not.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and members of his cabinet at the meeting with oil executives at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Trump’s $100 Billion Venezuela Oil Plan Gets a Cool Reception
item.description: President Trump met with oil and gas executives on Friday in an effort to push them to invest money in Venezuela, a plan many of them are reluctant to embrace.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump during a meeting with energy executives at the White House on Friday. He wants the biggest U.S. and European oil companies to pour at least $100 billion into Venezuela.

item.title: What Is El Helicoide, the Infamous Torture Prison in Venezuela?
item.description: As Venezuela’s interim authorities began to release political prisoners, some of their families raced to the notorious prison that symbolized Nicolás Maduro’s authoritarian rule.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Sulbarán and James Wagner
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: El Helicoide seen in Caracas on Thursday. It was first conceived as a futuristic mall before being repurposed to hold prisoners.

item.title: Freed Venezuelan Political Prisoner Called Maduro’s 2024 Victory a Fraud to His Face
item.description: Enrique Márquez, a centrist opposition lawmaker, refused to rubber-stamp the government’s dubious election results in front of the entire nation.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Federico Parra/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The former Venezuelan presidential candidate Enrique Márquez looking at a voting record during a news conference in the capital, Caracas, in 2024.

item.title: Venezuela’s Oil Industry: A Timeline of Key Events
item.description: The country’s oil industry has undergone major shifts and two waves of nationalization since its first well started pumping in 1914.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil rigs operated by the state-owned company Petróleos de Venezuela in the city of Cabimas. Venezuela is home to some of the world’s largest oil fields.

item.title: U.S. Boards Another Tanker Carrying Venezuelan Oil
item.description: The tanker, the Olina, is the fifth to be boarded or seized by U.S. forces in recent weeks as part of an effort to control Venezuela’s oil exports.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert, Eric Schmitt and Nicholas Nehamas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Maryorin Mendez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Silhouettes of children carrying a net at a fishing pier while in the background a crude oil tanker is docking in Venezuela’s Maracaibo Lake on Thursday.

item.title: E.U. and South America to Form Free-Trade Zone With 700 Million People
item.description: The agreement represents a push for deeper global cooperation, in contrast to the United States’ turning to coercion in its dealings with other countries.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Yves Herman
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, left, the president of the European Commission, meeting with Brazil’s president, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, at a Group of 20 summit in November.

item.title: Trump Indicates He Will Meet Venezuela’s Machado After Offer to Give Him Her Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: President Trump indicated that he would meet the Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado. Last year, she won the Nobel Peace Prize, an award he covets.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado, Venezuela’s opposition leader, at an election rally in Caracas in 2024.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott, Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

item.title: How an Abrupt Call Between Trump and Colombia’s President Averted a Crisis
item.description: President Gustavo Petro said that the new tone between the leaders was “friendly,” but he also resurfaced his deep disagreements with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal and Max Bearak
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia at the Presidential Palace in Bogotá, on Thursday, during an interview with The New York Times.

item.title: Wary of Investing in Venezuela, Big Oil Heads to the White House
item.description: The amounts of money, time and political uncertainty trouble executives at large Western oil companies, who plan to meet with President Trump on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue near the Venezuelan state oil company in Caracas. U.S. energy executives were far from ready to make a commitment when President Trump said they would “spend billions of dollars” in that country.

item.title: Venezuelans Decry Civilian Casualties. Pentagon Says It’s Unaware of Any.
item.description: For all Venezuelans, the nighttime raid opened a period of deep uncertainty. For the families of those killed, it meant the grim task of burying their relatives.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Friends and family at the burial of Rosa Elena González, 80, who was killed during the U.S. raid to capture Venezuela’s president, Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Once Again, a Newfoundland Town Rescues Stranded Passengers
item.description: After 9/11, Gander took in thousands of people whose flights were diverted. History repeated on a smaller scale this week.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: The airport in Gander, Newfoundland, where three flights were diverted this week for bad weather, stranding travelers.

item.title: U.S. Navy Is Chasing Several Oil Tankers in the Atlantic
item.description: A mass departure by sanctioned tankers, some switching to Russian flags, has triggered a fresh effort by the United States to pursue Venezuelan oil shipments at sea.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert, Riley Mellen and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: U.S. Southern Command
item.media:description: An image from video released by the U.S. military purporting to show the seizure of the oil tanker M Sophia in the Caribbean on Wednesday.

item.title: Rocío San Miguel, Venezuelan Political Prisoner, Was Among Those Released
item.description: Ms. San Miguel’s arrest in 2024 raised fears that Venezuela had entered a new era of repression.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Oscar Del Pozo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators demanding the release of Rocío San Miguel, one of Venezuela’s most prominent political prisoners, at a rally held in Madrid, last year.

item.title: Russian Propaganda Ramps Up After U.S. Raid in Venezuela
item.description: A network of websites known as “Portal Kombat” is spreading messages about U.S. military hardware, according to tracking firms.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Ramil Sitdikov/Reuters
item.media:description: Red Square in Moscow. Russia and Venezuela have had a close diplomatic relationship, and Moscow is keen to retain those ties.

item.title: Fact-Checking Trump’s Justifications for the Venezuela Operation
item.description: The president has repeatedly tied Venezuela to drug overdose deaths, claimed the Maduro regime sent an influx of criminal migrants and accused the country of stealing American oil.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at a news conference on Saturday at Mar-a-Lago.

item.title: Macron tells ambassadors that the world has become ‘unhinged.’
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Michel Euler
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France in Paris on Thursday. He told a group of global ambassadors that rules around the world had been discarded.

item.title: Venezuela Leaders Free Political Prisoners in a Sign of Possible Change
item.description: The interim government released some prisoners under pressure from the Trump administration, even as it continued arrests and crackdowns elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Emma Bubola, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Atali Cabrejo waits for the release of her son, Juan Jose Freites, outside El Helicoide prison in Caracas, Venezuela, on Thursday.

item.title: Senate Advances Measure to Curb Trump’s Use of Force in Venezuela
item.description: A handful of Republicans joined Democrats to allow the measure to move forward, reflecting concerns in both parties about the administration’s strategy.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: “Make no mistake: Bombing another nation’s capital and removing their president is an act of war, plain and simple,” Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, said before the vote.

item.title: Thomas Massie Thinks Trump and Republicans Are ‘Gaslighting’ on Venezuela
item.description: Representative Thomas Massie, a rare Republican critic of President Trump’s military intervention, explained his concerns in an interview with The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Thomas Massie, Republican of Kentucky, in November. In an interview on Wednesday, he slammed “a flimsy constitutional argument” for the United States’ seizure and prosecution of Venezuela’s leader.

item.title: Rubio Says He’ll Discuss Greenland With Danish Officials Next Week
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio told reporters he would speak with the officials after days of mounting threats from the Trump administration to take Greenland, a semiautonomous Danish territory.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said he would meet with Danish officials next week to discuss the future of Greenland.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Robert Jimison

item.title: Tips for Caribbean Vacations and Travel Insurance After Venezuela Operation
item.description: The recent military operation in Venezuela disrupted vacations to popular destinations. Here are tips for buying travel insurance and protecting your trip.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.media:credit: Ricardo Arduengo/Reuters
item.media:description: Passengers were stranded at Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport near San Juan, P.R., last weekend after the F.A.A. closed some airspace to U.S. civilian aircraft.

item.title: Colombia’s President Feared a U.S. Attack. Then Trump Called.
item.description: The conversation appeared to defuse a crisis that erupted after President Trump said military action against Colombia “sounds good.” President Gustavo Petro spoke to The New York Times just before the call.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Max Bearak and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia during an interview with The New York Times in Cartagena on Wednesday.
